data.title: Fake build
data.body: Run a fake AppVeyor build with the new matrix scheme :notes:

data.title: Bring master up to date with recent changes in 1.20-release branch
data.body:
We've been tweaking/debugging the build process on the 1.20-releases branch while seeking a resolution for https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15194. This PR brings the master branch up to date with those changes from the 1.20-releases branch.

/fyi @damieng @smashwilson

data.title: Please add explicit link to Package’s Github repo on Package settings file in Atom
data.body:
### Description

[Description of the issue]
The Package view for any particular package doesn’t include a direct link to the Github repo, which cold prove very helpful.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Preferences.
2. Select “Packages.”
3. Select any installed Package.
4. Notice there are only links to that Package’s Atom.io page, Github issues page (close!), the Changelog file, the License, and a “View Code” link.

**Expected behavior:** I come to the Package’s settings page to visit their Github Repo home page.

**Actual behavior:** I come here often expecting to see the link to the repo only to remember that I have to go through Atom.io.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom 1.18.0 x64

data.title: Graphical issue with long lines
data.body:
### Description

When i change to last space on a long line, the style of the editor changes.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Keep the cursor at the next line of a long line with the window maximized.

![captura01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29883979/29167988-2af3c6dc-7dcd-11e7-9468-216bd2532e5e.PNG)

2. Press the left arrow key.

![captura02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29883979/29167998-3ab03bf0-7dcd-11e7-9e52-d4a5a2736133.PNG)

3. If i move the cursor back and open a new tab the style comes back.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

OS: Microsoft Windows [Versión 10.0.15063]

###
Also i have seen some blur effect, but i don't know how to reproduce it.

data.body:

### Description

Atom editor crashed when tried to open multiple files from remote disk

data.body:
### Steps to reproduce

1. Launch Atom

### Abstract

An expected behavior of IME on TexEdit shows "あいうえお" with an bold underbar.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/706275/29155923-09f3a206-7dda-11e7-8523-7e21b9ad001d.png)

But, an actual behavior of IME on Atom shows "お" without an bold underbar and does not show "あいうえ".

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/706275/29155954-2deec118-7dda-11e7-9056-3df59fe7d9fe.png)

The IME' settings on my macOS is Japanese.

data.title: Buffer rewrite with beautify completely corrupts mixed-EOL files.
data.body:
I haven't proven this is the culprit, but all signs point to the [new editor backend in v1.19.0](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.19.0) (or another "improvement" in v1.19.0) getting confused when there are multiple types of line endings in a document and **completely corrupting the file** when you run https://github.com/Glavin001/atom-beautify on it. I'm using Atom 1.19.0 ia32 with atom-beautify 0.30.4 on Windows 10 Pro 64-bit. I'm attaching a zipped file that contains mixed LF and CRLF file. (Yes, it's horrible, but it's out of my control; see the end of this message for the back story.) Earlier editions of Atom would should the LF line endings using a different symbol, but _this version of Atom shows the LF line endings as if they were CRLF endings_ when I turn on invisibles. (The line ending notification at the bottom also says CRLF when the type is really mixed.) This is what tips me off that there is an underlying problem in the buffers, thinking that all the line endings are the same --- and when I went and saw the release notes that Atom updated it buffer implementation, that made it almost certain. Install the `atom-beautify` package and open the attached archive. (Don't copy and paste, or that will normalize the line endings.) Make sure the `.jsbeatifyrc` file is in the same directory. Then run `atom-beautify` on it. It will turn this: ```html ``` into this: ```html 
//someone's date of birth: May 30, 1970
    
Local dates and times are relative or floating; they do not provide sufficient information to determine precisely when an event occurred or will occur. Recording the date and time of a birth, for instance, must include the time zone. A journal entry as well would normally indicate the time zone in order to fix the exact moment in an absolute way worldwide: December 11, 2016 10:53 a.m. America/Los Angeles.

```

Yes, basically it just jumps around, drops large sections of content, and copies other pieces of content to other locations.

If I first take the HTML file into another editor (e.g. EmEditor) and normalize the line endings (either all CRLF or all LF), the bug does not occur and `atom-beautify` functions as it usually does. This proves the bug has to do with mixed line endings, and everything about it points to new overhaul in a recent version of Atom.

**This is a huge, breaking, content corrupting bug.**

Yes, I have mixed line endings. No, I didn't want them to begin with. One of the reasons I'm opening them in Atom _is so that `atom-beautify` can normalize them_!!! **No editor should corrupt my content just because my EOLs are not consistent.**

No matter what I do, my toolchain just keeps developing bugs:

* The BlueGriffon HTML editor has a huge [bug](https://github.com/therealglazou/bluegriffon/issues/7) from deep in the Mozilla code, which adds newlines when it shouldn't --- but to make matters worse, it adds an LF in the middle of a file using CRLF on a Windows machine, producing mixed line endings. I have put my money out as a [bounty](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/29803090-line-wrapping-setting-ignored) to get this fixed, but there have been no takers.
* I use `atom-beautify` to attempt to reformat the file: to normalize the line endings, and get rid of the extra newlines. This only halfway works; many of the erroneous newlines remain because of a `js-beautify` [bug](https://github.com/beautify-web/js-beautify/issues/1033). I have also paid my money on a [bounty](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/41908855-not-correctly-joining-lines-for-html) to get this fixed, but no one seems interested.
* Now it would appear that Atom not only can't process EOLs correctly, it also corrupts the files. I can't win for losing.

See https://github.com/beautify-web/js-beautify/issues/1225 and https://github.com/Glavin001/atom-beautify/issues/1802 for further discussion and "bellyaching" as we say.

I need some tequila.

[atom-buffer-mixed-eol-bug.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1213599/atom-buffer-mixed-eol-bug.zip)

data.title: Set multiline flags for out-of-Atom regex replacements
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

A very simple one-liner.  The `m` flag wasn't being added when doing a regex replacement on files not opened in Atom.  For those who aren't aware, `m` changes the meaning of `^` and `$` to mean "begin/end of line", rather than "begin/end of string" (which can be generalized to "begin/end of file" in Atom's case).  The behavior that `m` introduces is consistent with what most developers view `^` and `$` as, and is also what find-and-replace visually shows in the results view.  Therefore, this change fixes the discrepancy between the visual, expected result and the actual result when the regex contains a `^` or `$` and the matched string is not the first/last line in the file.

text-buffer already adds the `m` flag when replacing files inside of Atom.
https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/blob/bb9134fc93713273dcccafd9e917e00f1f2f58cc/src/text-buffer.coffee#L1326

### Alternate Designs

None.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

`atom.workspace.replace()` is a public API.

### Benefits

When searching with a regex that contains a `^` or `$`, replacements should now work as expected.

### Possible Drawbacks

There is one drawback: there is no way to return to the non-multiline behavior of `^` and `$` once the flag is set.  JavaScript does not yet support `\A` and `\Z`.

### Applicable Issues

Refs atom/find-and-replace#622

data.title: Editor crashes while editing files on network drive
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom crashes while editing a file from a network drive. 
I use a drive mounted from my macbook on my windows computer to edit from time to time. While editing the files, if at any time I try to run the files (e.g. `rails s`) or any other command, or sometimes just for no reason, I get the "The Editor has crashed" alert and have to reload the window. Nothing is showing up in the developer tools. I've tried both mounting the drive in windows and directly accesing them via the file browser (`\\mymacbook\dev\projectfolder`)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file from a network/remote drive
2. Run a command  on the files (e.g. `npm install`, `bundle exec`) and the editor will crash

**Expected behavior:** Editor doesn't crash while editing remote files

**Actual behavior:** Atom crashes and I have to fully reload the program

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

data.title: [1.19.0] "View > Show Tab Bar" option gone
data.body: Prior 1.19.0, I used Atom with multiple project tabs (not regular tabs), so I can switch easy in between project while using the same window. After upgrade, the `View > Show Tab Bar` option is gone on my Sierra Mac. Was this option relocated or replaced with a new feature? Reverting back to 1.18.x solves the issue.

data.title: Minor blur applied to editor after scrolling down.
data.body:
### Description

Whenever I scroll down to the bottom of a file, a minor blur is added to the editor, slightly blurring all text, and only returns to normal once I scroll back up. Here is a screenshot before scrolling down entirely: https://prnt.sc/g6ixmp and here is a screenshot after: https://prnt.sc/g6ixyr. If you switch back and forth between tabs, you can clearly notice a difference, which has been bothering me since I noticed it. 

This does not happen to files that fit entirely on my screen, as there is nothing to scroll to. It only occurs when I scroll down while viewing a file, and reach the complete bottom, then this minor blur will affect that file only, until I scroll up entirely to the top. 

I have tried switching UI/syntax, disabling all the packages I use, restarting Atom, and it keeps happening.

### Versions
Atom: 1.19.0

OS: Windows 8

data.title: The editor has crashed
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode - **doesn't crash in safe mode, but it still crashes in normal mode and I do not wish to switch to safe mode for all usage**
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom - **unreasonable, I cannot read 4600 issues to find this exact crash, but I don't see it on the first page**
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages - **irrelevant, not looking for a package**

### Description

Since updating to Atom 1.19.0 (my tenth update), it crashes every time I run it.

### Steps to Reproduce

0. Install and enable the [git-gui] package

1. Launch Atom
2. Press ctrl-comma to open settings
3. Click Packages

OR simply:

1. Launch Atom (after doing the above steps once)

**Expected behavior:** Atom runs and I'm able to browse the packages list

**Actual behavior:** The deprecated packages never finish loading, and the core app seg faults:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1559108/29142005-12ec11dc-7d16-11e7-8cb4-8d1aa06bc77c.png)

stdout and ~/.atom/nohup.out both say:

```
/usr/bin/atom: line 130: 19908 Segmentation fault      (core dumped) nohup "$ATOM_PATH" --executed-from="$(pwd)" --pid=$$ "$@" > "$ATOM_HOME/nohup.out" 2>&1
(node:19908) MaxListenersExceededWarning: Possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 focus listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners() to increase limit
(node:19908) MaxListenersExceededWarning: Possible EventEmitter memory leak detected. 11 blur listeners added. Use emitter.setMaxListeners() to increase limit
Failed to generate minidump.
```
("Failed to generate minidump." is repeated 1210 times on that line, omitted for brevity.)

Browsing installed packages is kind of important after an update because some old packages might need to be updated, disabled, configured, or removed.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0
```

Ubuntu 17.04

### Additional Information

Only happens if [git-gui] is installed and enabled.

[git-gui]: https://github.com/andrewrynhard/atom-git-gui

data.title: Find in Project returns no results when path contains forward slashes (/)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Find in Project returns no results when file/directory pattern contains forward slashes. Backslashes are required to separate directories.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Find in Project panel.
2. In the File/directory pattern field, enter a path with forward slashes. For instance, `src/foo/bar`.
3. Search for text that is known to exist in the specified directory. No results are found.
4. Change the path to use backslashes. For instance, `src\foo\bar`. Now, results are found.

**Expected behavior:** File/directory pattern should return the same results, regardless of whether file/directory pattern contains forward slashes or backslashes. This matches the behavior of the vast majority of Windows apps.

**Actual behavior:** When file/directory pattern contains forward slashes, search returns no results.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

OS: Windows 10 x64

### Additional Information

\-

data.title: Debug missing snapshot auxiliary data
data.body: Let's do some in-CI debugging to see where our snapshot auxiliary data (notable, the Less compile cache) is getting dropped.

data.title: Weird when editing text which is partial selected. (with required Prerequisites)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Select a part of a string and type a letter, the selection should disappear but not move to the right part of the string, this is a DEMO


![demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2340296/29136116-cede213e-7d6e-11e7-89b6-916e08ab2999.gif)



### Steps to Reproduce

1. File -> New File;
2. Input a string `aaaaabbbbbccccc`;
3. Select the middle part of the string `bbbbb`;
4. While still holding down the mouse button. Type a letter `x`;

**Expected behavior:** The text becomes `aaaaaxccccc` and no charcters are selected.

**Actual behavior:** The text becomes `aaaaaxccccc` but the middle 4 `c` are selected.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% reproduce.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

MacOS Sierra 10.12.6 

### Additional Information
I did the steps more than 10 times, every time it reproduce. But it will not reproduce when you use undo to get the selection back after type the letter `x`, like typing `cmd-z`.

Another problem is when I select some strings and hit backspace, the selected strings are deleted but strings next to the deleted one are automatically selected.

data.title: Weird when editing text which is partial selected
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

I don't think the prerequistes is needed this time.

### Description

Pretty difficult to describe, this is a [demo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/yubaoquan/yubaoquan.github.io/master/images/selection.gif) picture.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Type some text in the editor, for example `aaaaabbbbb`.
2. Select the left part of the text like `aaaaa`.
3. Type a letter `x`.


**Expected behavior:** the text becomes `xbbbbb` and no charcters are selected.
**Actual behavior:** the text becomes `xbbbbb` but the middle 4 `b` are selected.

**Reproduces how often:** Many times, but not every time.

### Versions

1.19.0

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'id' of null
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. ...justo copy and paste a json 
[
    {
        "local": [
            {
                "group": {
                    "id": "<some string id>"
                }
            }
        ],
        "remote": [
            {
                "type": "Email"
            }
        ]
    }
]

2. ...

**Atom**: 1.19.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.6.9
**OS**: Unknown Windows version
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

```

data.title: Huge memory consumption upon startup
data.body:
I run Atom inside a VirtualBox (5.1.24) Linux Mint 18.2 MATE guest (on a Win7 host). Any released version of Atom higher than 1.16, including the recently released 1.19, consumes such a huge amount of memory upon startup, that it effectively halts/OOMs my VM.
Watching memory consumption upon startup, in 1.16 it consumes about 1GB total before settling back down to 400-500MB. But above 1.16, it consumes around 2.4GB while starting up - or more likely that is simply all that is available in my VM.
Something changed in 1.17 to gobble up all that memory. Amazing if nobody else is having an issue with this. I have tried disabling all plugins, no diff.
I'm obviously stuck on 1.16 until this is resolved.
Thanks.

data.title: Half of the workspace is unusable
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The workspace only reaches the middle of the screen, in the empty half can not take any action.
This problem has only affected large projects like [this.](http://i.imgur.com/rTeuOiv.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Be on Windows 10 Home
2. Open a large project on Atom

**Expected behavior:** Open the project without problems

**Actual behavior:** Half of the workspace is unusable

**Reproduces how often:** Always in these last 3 weeks

### Versions

OS: Windows 10 Home v.1703

Atom: 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome: 56.0.2924.87
Node: 7.4.0

apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python
git 2.8.1.windows.1
visual studio

data.title: [1.19.0] Reveal in tree view not selecting file when all parent directories are closed
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Reveal in tree view doesn't select current file if all parent directories are closed.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom window in root directory of project
2. Open a file nested somewhere deep in the folder structure
3. Close all parent directories in tree view
4. right click on open file and select `reveal in tree view`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
The current file to be selected in the tree view.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Root directory is still selected.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.8
git 2.10.1

### Additional Information

data.title: Separate tests and installer creation on AppVeyor
data.body: Let's try using a build matrix to split installer creation into a different job than the linting and tests. Hopefully this will help us sneak builds in under the AppVeyor time cutoff.

data.title: no UI after 1.20.0-beta0 update
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After the update to 1.20.0-beta0 version, no UI is loaded. When Atom is lunched (opening some *.adoc/*.c file), only black window is appear. When the file is open from menu View->Developer->Open In Dev Mode then the UI is loaded and content of file is displayed.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. update to 1.20.0-beta0
2. open any *.adoc / *.c file

**Expected behavior:** The UI is loaded and content of file is displayed

**Actual behavior:** Only black window with menu bar is displayed

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of time

### Versions

Atom    : 1.20.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.3                                                                                                                                                                                             npm  3.10.10                                                                                                                                                                                            node 6.9.5 x64                                                                                                                                                                                          python 3.6.0                                                                                                                                                                                            git 2.11.0.windows.1                                                                                                                                                                                    visual studio

Windows 10 version 1703 build 15063.540

### Additional Information

N/A

data.title: Touch Bar support
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

There is currently no support of the Touch Bar on the new MacBook Pro 2017

### Steps to Reproduce

No steps

**Expected behavior:** Should have useful shortcuts on the Touch Bar

**Actual behavior:** Nothing

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

macOS Sierra:
- `atom --version`:
```
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
- `apm --version`:
```
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.13.3
```
### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
